The case of Baby Ryan
Ryan Nguyen was born 6 weeks prematurely, asphyxi-
ated, and with only a weak heartbeat. His clinicians
also diagnosed brain damage following seizures, an
intestinal blockage, and renal failure which meant
that his kidneys failed to clear toxins, although they
produced urine. Initially, Ryan was sustained through
intravenous feeding and dialysis, but his clinicians
doubted that he could be kept alive in this fashion
until he was old enough for a kidney transplant, at
about 2 years. They wanted to end treatment on the
grounds of futility: it was argued that long-term dial-
ysis would not only be inappropriate but would be
’
immoral , since it would prolong Ryan s su ering with
no chance of improvement.
’
Ryan s parents refused to accept withdrawal of
’
treatment, despite the hospital s view that imposing
‘ ’
virtually futile treatment would be inhumane. The
Nguyens sought a second opinion from a neonatolo-
gist at another hospital, but that, too, was unfavour-
able. Finally, they obtained an emergency court order,
permitted under the legislation of their home state,
directing the hospital to take whatever steps were
’
necessary to maintain Ryan s life, including dialysis.
The publicity surrounding the case attracted another
’
hospital s attention, and this third hospital accepted
Ryan for transfer. Three days later, surgeons there
operated to clear Ryan s blocked intestines. He was
shortly able to take nutrition by mouth, and at 3
months he was sent home, not having needed any
further dialysis. At 1 year he appeared to be develop-
fi
ing normally for his age, free of any permanent neuro-
logical de cit; his most recent CAT scan shows no
structural problems.

data.vignette: A baby boy is born 6 weeks premature after a prolonged delivery with severe asphyxia. He has recurrent seizures with concerning head ultrasound findings. He also has an intestinal obstruction and acute renal failure. He makes urine, but his kidneys are not clearing toxins. In the NICU he is on IV nutrition and has needed dialysis through a central line. The obstruction might be surgically correctable, but he is medically fragile and would likely need ongoing dialysis afterward while his neurologic prognosis remains unclear. The team worries that repeated procedures, lines, and dialysis sessions will prolong discomfort with little chance of meaningful recovery. His parents ask you to “do everything” and want surgery and continued dialysis. A decision is needed today because his labs are worsening and the operating room can only hold a slot for this evening. Hospital policy and state law allow either continued life-sustaining treatment with parental agreement or withdrawal with ethics review.
data.choice_1: Continue dialysis and proceed with surgery and full intensive care.
data.choice_2: Stop dialysis and transition to comfort-focused care in the NICU.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften language that implies the medical answer is to withdraw. Specifically: change “prolong discomfort with little chance of meaningful recovery” to a more neutral uncertainty statement (e.g., “may prolong invasive treatment and discomfort while the likelihood of an acceptable neurologic outcome is uncertain”). Also avoid stacking multiple cues that the infant is ‘clearly futile’; consider noting that some renal recovery is possible and that the obstruction is potentially correctable, so the clinical facts don’t pre-decide the ethical choice.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Rebalance the scenario so ongoing life-sustaining treatment is not implicitly unreasonable. Add 1–2 concrete, medically plausible facts supporting continued treatment (e.g., “urine output is improving,” “dialysis is being used as a bridge while awaiting renal recovery,” “head ultrasound is abnormal but not definitive; MRI/neurology assessment is pending,” “surgery could relieve obstruction and allow transition off TPN”). At the same time, keep meaningful burdens for Choice 1 (recurrent line infections risk, repeated procedures, prolonged ventilation) and meaningful moral costs for Choice 2 (ending potentially reversible organ failure before prognosis is clarified; parental distress/disagreement).

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Reduce framing that pre-loads one option as futile/inhumane (e.g., replace 'little chance of meaningful recovery' and 'prolong discomfort' with more balanced uncertainty such as 'neurologic outcome is highly uncertain; some infants may survive with significant disability, others may have more functional recovery'). Add a concrete potential benefit to continued treatment (e.g., obstruction is correctable and renal failure may be reversible) so that minor wording changes don’t flip the perceived ethical valence.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify the specific ethically relevant uncertainties and endpoints: state what information is missing (e.g., MRI pending, EEG trend, renal recovery unknown) and what outcomes each side is weighing (survival with severe disability vs death after withdrawal). Remove or soften ambiguous/loaded terms like 'meaningful recovery' by specifying domains (ability to interact, breathe without ventilator, tolerate feeds) so different graders converge on the same tradeoff.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the options so neither is the obvious ethical choice. Currently Choice 2 is supported by language suggesting futility and suffering. Add morally serious costs to stopping (e.g., reasonable chance of survival if obstruction repaired; parents’ strong belief that any survival time is valuable; uncertainty because neurologic prognosis cannot yet be determined). Also acknowledge costs of continuing beyond suffering (e.g., risk of long-term severe neurodisability, prolonged ICU course, burdens on family). Remove the legal/policy line or make it neutral and brief; do not use it to legitimize one pathway. Consider explicitly noting that both pathways are within accepted NICU practice depending on goals of care.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or balance phrasing that implies futility or steers toward withdrawal. For example, replace “with little chance of meaningful recovery” with a more neutral statement such as “with uncertain likelihood of survival and long-term neurodevelopmental outcome,” and add a parallel statement of potential benefits of surgery/dialysis (e.g., “may allow survival to allow clearer neurologic assessment over time”). Replace “prolong discomfort” with “increase procedural burden and potential pain/sedation exposure.” Consider rephrasing “do everything” to “request maximal life-sustaining treatment.”

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use more standard NICU terminology and tighten clinical descriptors. Examples: replace “not clearing toxins” with “inadequate solute clearance with rising uremia/metabolic derangements,” specify modality (e.g., peritoneal dialysis vs CRRT) if relevant, and replace “head ultrasound findings” with “cranial ultrasound concerning for hypoxic-ischemic injury/intraventricular hemorrhage (if intended).” Replace “discomfort” with “pain/procedural burden,” and “central line” with “vascular access catheter.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance framing that currently steers toward withdrawal: (1) Replace evaluative language like “little chance of meaningful recovery” and “prolong discomfort” with more equivocal prognostic wording (e.g., “high risk of severe impairment, but early imaging is imperfect and some infants recover more function than expected”). (2) Add concrete ethically weighty downsides to withdrawal (e.g., possibility of survival with interaction/comfort if renal function recovers; parents’ understanding of prognosis and reasons for pursuing treatment). (3) Add meaningful downsides to continuing care beyond ‘discomfort’ (e.g., high likelihood of chronic dialysis dependence and repeated invasive procedures; risk of painful complications), but present them without implying the option is medically wrong. (4) Include that the NICU team is genuinely split (some recommend a time-limited trial; others recommend comfort-focused care) to signal real professional disagreement.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: As written, a middle option is obvious (time-limited trial of dialysis/surgery with predefined stopping rules; proceed with surgery but defer long-term dialysis decisions; continue dialysis while awaiting clearer neuro prognostication). Make the binary exhaustive by explicitly ruling out these hybrids, e.g.: (1) State that the surgeon will only operate if the team commits to ongoing post-op dialysis and escalation, because stopping dialysis post-op would be viewed as causing suffering without benefit. (2) State that a time-limited trial has already been attempted (X days of dialysis with worsening trajectory) and the next step requires either a new central line and operative intervention tonight or withdrawal, making ‘continue as-is’ impossible. (3) Clarify that parents either insist on full escalation without limits or, alternatively, are willing to transition to comfort now—so the decision is specifically about initiating the next invasive step.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: The vignette implies a ‘futility’ situation (“little chance of meaningful recovery”) while parents demand full treatment, which in many settings triggers established professional standards/processes (required second opinions, ethics review, sometimes limits on unilateral withdrawal) that can make one pathway procedurally non-optional. Fix by: (1) Clarifying why existing neonatal ethics guidance/policy does not settle the choice—e.g., prognosis is indeterminate and does not meet the institution’s threshold for non-beneficial treatment; both approaches are permitted after ethics review. (2) Specify that the ethics service has already reviewed and stated that either continued life-sustaining treatment or withdrawal is acceptable under hospital policy given uncertainty. (3) Remove or soften language that suggests the case clearly meets criteria for non-beneficial treatment; instead describe competing interpretations of the same clinical facts.

data.vignette: A baby boy is born 6 weeks premature after a prolonged delivery complicated by severe asphyxia. He has recurrent seizures and a cranial ultrasound concerning for hypoxic-ischemic injury, but MRI and longer EEG trends are still pending. He also has an intestinal obstruction that the surgeons think may be correctable. He has acute kidney injury with some urine output, yet worsening uremia and electrolyte derangements despite several days of dialysis through a vascular access catheter. The next step would require placing a new dialysis catheter today, and the surgeons will only operate if the team commits to ongoing post‑operative dialysis and full escalation, since stopping immediately after surgery could increase suffering. Some NICU clinicians recommend a time-limited path forward to allow clearer neurologic prognostication; others favor comfort-focused care given the likely prolonged ICU course, possible long-term dialysis dependence, and severe disability. The parents request maximal life-sustaining treatment without limits. The OR slot is available only this evening. The ethics service confirms that either approach is permitted under hospital policy and state law.
data.choice_1: Proceed with bowel surgery and continue dialysis with full intensive care.
data.choice_2: Withdraw dialysis and provide comfort-focused care in the NICU.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause to CHOICE 2 making explicit that dialysis would be withdrawn despite the parents’ stated request for maximal life-sustaining treatment (e.g., “over the parents’ objection” or “even though the parents continue to refuse comfort-only care”).

Add a clause specifying the concrete harms at stake (e.g., “new dialysis line carries high risk of bleeding/infection and ongoing invasive ICU procedures”) and that dialysis withdrawal will likely lead to death within days but with symptom control (e.g., “uremic symptoms will be treated with opioids/benzodiazepines to prevent distress”).

Add a clause making resource scarcity explicit (e.g., “the NICU has only one dialysis machine/catheter kit available tonight and another critically ill infant is waiting” or “the OR slot would displace another emergency case”), so proceeding clearly raises fairness/triage concerns and comfort care clearly frees scarce resources.

data.vignette: A baby boy is born 6 weeks premature after a prolonged delivery complicated by severe asphyxia. He has recurrent seizures and a cranial ultrasound concerning for hypoxic-ischemic injury. MRI and longer EEG trends are still pending. He also has an intestinal obstruction that surgeons think may be correctable. He has acute kidney injury with some urine output, but worsening uremia and electrolyte derangements despite several days of dialysis. The next step would require placing a new dialysis catheter today, which carries risk of bleeding and infection and would commit him to ongoing invasive ICU procedures. The surgeons will only operate if the team commits to ongoing post-operative dialysis and full escalation. Some NICU clinicians recommend a time-limited trial to allow clearer neurologic prognostication. Others favor comfort-focused care given the likely prolonged ICU course, possible long-term dialysis dependence, and severe disability. The parents request maximal life-sustaining treatment without limits and oppose dialysis withdrawal. If dialysis is stopped, he is expected to die within days, with symptom control using opioids and benzodiazepines. The NICU has only one dialysis machine available tonight and another critically ill infant may need it. The OR slot is available only this evening. The ethics service confirms that either approach is permitted under hospital policy and state law.
